questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Thessalonians 1:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'work of faith and labor of love' (v.3) and the description of their turning from idols (v.9).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'work of faith and labor of love and steadfastness of hope' (v.3)
Pay attention to the contrast between their past idolatry and current devotion to God (v.9)
The phrase 'turned from idols to serve the living and true God' is a powerful declaration of conversion

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Thessalonians) is being thanked by Paul, WHAT (their faith, love, and hope) they have demonstrated, WHERE (in the church of Thessalonica and the surrounding regions), and WHY (because they were chosen by God and turned from idols).
tips: Include the fact that their faith spread to Macedonia and Achaia (v.6)
Note that they became imitators of Paul and the Lord (v.6)
Their turning from idols to God (v.9) is a key event

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: their turning from idols (v.9), becoming imitators of Paul (v.6), or the phrase 'work of faith and labor of love' (v.3).
tips: The Thessalonians' decision to turn from idols to serve the living God is a profound act of faith and obedience
Becoming imitators of Paul and the Lord shows they were transformed by the gospel
The phrase 'work of faith and labor of love' highlights the active nature of their faith

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Thessalonica through this passage?
tips: Paul is affirming their genuine conversion and the positive impact of their faith
He emphasizes that they were chosen by God and their response to the gospel was transformative
This passage serves as encouragement for the church to maintain their faith and hope in Christ's return

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'imitators' (v.6), the meaning of 'turned from idols' (v.9), or the idea of 'waiting for His Son from heaven' (v.9).
tips: 'Imitators' refers to following Paul's example and Christ's example in daily life, not just in theory
Idols in the ancient context included false gods and practices that the Thessalonians were part of in their city
Waiting for the Son from heaven means looking forward to Christ's return (the Parousia), which is a future hope

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'work of faith, labor of love, and steadfastness of hope' (v.3) this week?
tips: Identify an area where you need to increase your work of faith (e.g., prayer, study)
Consider how you can labor in love through service or acts of kindness
Pray for steadfast hope in Christ's return, especially when facing trials

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the Thessalonians' example of turning from idols to Christ and for their steadfast hope in His return.
tips: Thank God for the Thessalonians' conversion and their impact on the church
Pray for courage to turn away from sin and toward Christ
Ask God to strengthen your hope in His return

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 1 Thessalonians 5:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between 'the day of the Lord coming like a thief' and 'children of light'.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'children of light' (v.5) and 'the day of the Lord' (v.2)
Pay attention to the contrast between 'sleeping' (v.6) and 'being sober' (v.6)
The phrase 'for God has not destined them for wrath but for salvation' (v.9) is a key theological statement

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the church in Thessalonica is being warned about, WHAT they must do, WHERE this warning applies, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include the church in Thessalonica as the audience
Note that the day of the Lord comes unexpectedly (like a thief)
Highlight the contrast between being children of light and the world of darkness

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of the day of the Lord (v.2-3), the call to be sober (v.6), or the promise of salvation (v.9-10)?
tips: The phrase 'they are all children of light' (v.5) is powerful because it identifies the church as distinct from the world
The contrast between 'sleeping' (v.6) and 'being sober' (v.6) shows active readiness
The promise that God has not destined them for wrath but for salvation (v.9) is a comforting assurance

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Thessalonica through this passage?
tips: Paul is warning against complacency while emphasizing the church's identity as children of light and their destiny in salvation
The main point is that the church must live in readiness for the day of the Lord, not in fear but in hope, because they are destined for salvation through Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The nature of the day of the Lord, the concept of 'children of light', or the promise of salvation?
tips: The phrase 'the day of the Lord comes like a thief' (v.2) is a metaphor that might be misinterpreted as a sudden, destructive event without warning
The term 'children of light' (v.5) is a theological concept that contrasts with the 'darkness' of the world, but it's not about literal light
The promise that God has not destined them for wrath but for salvation (v.9) requires understanding that salvation is by grace through Christ, not by human effort

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of being 'children of light' and 'rejoicing always' to your week?
tips: Identify one area where you might be 'sleeping' (avoiding responsibility) and take a step to be 'sober' (active and alert)
Practice 'rejoicing always' by sharing a thanksgiving with a friend this week
Commit to one act of 'praying without ceasing' (v.11) by setting aside 5 minutes each day for prayer

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the promise of salvation and ask for the strength to live as children of light.
tips: Thank God that He has not destined us for wrath but for salvation through Christ
Ask for the courage to be sober and active in the church, not sleeping or being drunk
Pray for the church to be 'rejoicing always' and 'giving thanks in all circumstances'
